Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project lies in the core technology's ability to establish a new paradigm for oil spill cleanup that employs on-demand manufacturing of absorbent structures customized to match the specific properties of the oil to be collected. Oil spills are typically expensive to remediate due to the equipment, time, and manpower required. Consequently, most remediation approaches are focused on large-scale spill events. However, these account for only approximately 5% of the total pollution in waterways. Small-scale spills occur much more frequently but are often ignored because existing cleanup technologies are inefficient to deploy. The 3D printed oil absorbent technology to be explored in this project uniquely address this need by delivering customized absorbent capacity and the ability to be produced on-demand to maximize recovery for a broad range incidents via customization toward the unique combination of oil properties, quantity, and environmental and weather conditions at each spill site.

This I-Corps project seeks to explore the commercial potential of a family of 3D printable oleophilic materials capable of absorbing and retaining oil within specially designed internal pore networks. These absorbent materials also leverage shape memory behavior, making it possible for the absorbed oil to be extracted and recovered by heating the material to a prescribed temperature at which it automatically contracts to squeeze out the collected oil. In this way, the absorbent materials can be made to function like a self-wringing sponge. These materials are produced using poly(lactic acid), an inexpensive commodity biopolymer that is degradable and environmentally friendly. This technology emerged from fundamental research performed in a prior NSF-sponsored project, where optimal pore network designs and processing conditions were identified to maximize recovery of different petroleum samples dispersed in water. 3D printing enables on-demand production of designer absorbent architectures that match properties of different petroleum fractions, maximize selectivity against water, and permit either strong encapsulation or easy recovery of the collected oil.

POR.DRECONTENT:
EL Outcomes Summary

Our team, 990 “PrintSorb”, explored a technology for manufacturing 3D printed rigid oil absorbents to help marina managers who want to clean up small scale oil spills with lower material cost. As part of the customer discovery efforts performed in this I-Corps project, we conducted 108 in-person interviews and 8 phone interviews.

We began our I-Corps journey by focusing on the environmental threat posed by small scale oil spills. Despite the enormous collective hazard posed by these frequent spills, they are rarely cleaned up because oil absorbents currently on the market are designed to treat large-scale spills. We therefore hypothesized that our oil absorbents could fill a market need.

During our first phase of customer discovery, we tested our hypothesis by targeting marina staff, end users of our product, who deal with small oil spills routinely. However, marina managers did not observe any drawbacks in currently available products (absorbent pads and powders), which are produced at commodity scale and can be purchased at a very low price. One key customer interview with an oil spill cleaning contractor also cited one of our product’s innovative features, reusability, as being unfavorable because of its potential to cut the contractors’ profit.

Our second round of customer discovery focused on other elements of the business model canvas: competitors, regulators, and resellers. We found out that oil absorbents are commodity products, and our solution did not fit into this category. Instead, our products fall into the high-end spectrum where the additional features and cost may be justified. We began to search for other markets, and consequently made a pivot as one end user suggested presenting our products as bilge water filters to prevent spill rather than clean up spills. As this key interview occurred at one week prior to the closure of the training, we concluded our customer discovery with a “no go” decision and a clear next-step in plan at the final presentation.

After conclusion of the formal six-week program, we continued follow-up customer discovery activities focusing on a new group of customers: boat owners and boat manufacturers. As we redefined our products as a spill prevention solution, we found that the best season to present our products is before the starting of boat season, the spring of each year. Therefore, our exploration of this spill prevention market during late summer (June to September) put us at a disadvantage in terms of timing. However, we plan to continue these efforts in the spring. In addition, we further identified that large ships (as opposed to personal watercraft) could greatly benefit from our products, which led us to explore commercial, US Navy, and cruise companies who own and operate large ships.

 

PI Outcomes Summary

The PI has completely revamped a master's level biotechnology seminar course he teaches each fall to be centered around the business model framework. A key learning objective of this course is for students to take a professional inventory and craft personal statements that help define their interests and goals as a starting point to identify potential employers and faculty advisory committee members. Beginning in Fall 2017, the PI framed this exercise in the context of a personal business model as described in the book Business Model You: A One-Page Method for Reinventing Your Career, by Osterwalder, et. al., now a required text for the course. The PI also introduced lectures and deliverables that follow the required textbook. Notably, the business model canvas framework is introduced to expose students to entrepreneurship. 

Initial feedback from students has been extremely positive. Students have specifically cited the introduction to the business model canvas as beneficial in preparing them for business courses they are currently taking this spring, placing them ahead of peers who have not been previously exposed to this framework. The PI plans to continue to leverage this course as a launchpad to professional development and entrepreneurship. Specifically, he is working to introduce customer discovery activities centered around a “Hacking for Impact” framework, the methodology behind the successful Hacking for Defense curriculum, started at Stanford University in 2016 and now being used at ten U.S. universities.

None of this would have happened if the PI had not been engaged in the I-Corps expereince. It has truly transformed his teaching.

 


Last Modified: 03/20/2018
Modified by: Victor M Ugaz
